2.author: UnderTheRadarGun
2.body:
Thank you for that.  It is heart sinking.     

Yes. I just read a book, “Are We Smart Enough To Know How Smart Animals Are?” - Franz De Waal. It is well done as far as showing that animals are so much more like us, than we think. They have high intelligence (even if we don’t see it because it may be expressed in different ways), they have all the complex emotions we have, they have individual personalities, they have complex lives and agendas, they love their children, take care of their ill, mourn their dead, feel joy, and anger, etc. He uses several experiments and observations to support this. Something I learned on my own, but wanted to hear the scientific take.     

The thing that surprised me is, he again and again states his confusion about how, with such clear evidence there is such resistance in both the scientific and laymen, that they are as they are. I keep yelling at him, “People make up religion, deny human caused climate change, deny Covid, elections, that the earth goes round the sun, on and on, for “justification“ to do whatever they want. They lie to themselves that animals are mostly void functions of life SO THAT THEY CAN USE THEM GUILT FREE FOR ANYTHING THEY WANT.  In this case no trains hitting bison, and open land for their own farming and cattle.     

We torture them by the millions in lab and product testing. We destroy wetlands and forest for urban sprawl. We farm them for meat, or worse yet because we like their coats, even though we could stay warmer other ways. We pluck(ed) them from the wild to cage them as slaves for our entertainment. We deny them their own kind so they have no other choice but to express their need for love toward us as pets in some sick forced Stockholm Syndrome captivity. We breed them in ways that is unhealthy for them, because we like snubbed noses or downturned ears.     

The only way we can do all of this is to see them as something less than they are. Which of course plays well into believing we are some sort of divine image of God. We treat them like colonizers treat Native Americans or any other peoples. Manifest Destiny means “Gawd” wants us to kill them and take their lands and disregard their value because he wants us to have everything because they are savages and we are something higher. No. No, we’re not.

2.author: JustSomeApparition
2.body:
To believe something is simply the attitude we have when we accept something to be the case or regard it as true. To believe something needn’t involve actively reflecting on it. It can be done simply for the sake of doing.

The problem is that justify/justification it's often done based on one's beliefs; however, there is another component of the word justify/justification that is often overlooked... whether or not it is reasonable.

Just because a person believes something to be a certain way does not necessarily mean whatever course of action they take is a reasonable course of action.

If you believe that unicorns are the evil spawn of clouds is one thing. To justify the slaughter of unicorns because of that belief does not make it a reasonable course of action.

But here we have a problem again... Reasonable is also dependent on whether or not we believe a thing to be reasonable.

So in the end we are basing justifications for our actions on a single predeterminer whenever the word design is meant for it to be cross-checked. We set ourselves up for failure by not allowing the cross check process to happen.

Who calls the shots at a public company?

11.author: _Dnikeb
11.body:
>Officially, the seasons are held to start on the astronomical dates. Every year, around Dec. 21, we see a ton of news stories about how winter is about to officially start

Ask a Canadian meteorologist and they will confirm to you that even in Canada meteorological seasons start the first of the month. It's a universally agreed upon scientific standard. The only difference is that in Canada most people are oblivious to it, while in Australia it's common knowledge. So seasons don't _actually_ start earlier in Oz.

11.author: doc_daneeka
11.body:
> Ask a Canadian meteorologist and they will confirm to you that even in Canada meteorological seasons start the first of the month.

I'm not disputing that.  What I am saying is that winter is generally considered to start on the solstice, whatever the meteorologists feel about the matter.  And in Australia, the general view is that it starts on the meteorological date, and I like that system better.

Not sure where you are in the world, but if you go to Canada or the USA and ask people when the seasons officially start, almost everyone is going to go with the astronomical dates, because that is the common usage.  Go to Australia, and you will find that this is not the case.  My point is that I like their common usage more than ours.

11.author: _Dnikeb
11.body: I know that. It's what I've been trying to tell you this entire time. Meteorological seasons make more sense than astronomical seasons. Australians know it, most Canadians don't. But it's not like Australia is under some magic spell that makes seasons start earlier. That's it, that's my whole point. Not sure why we're arguing since we're saying the same exact thing.

31.author: moonknuckles
31.body:
>it's not like alcoholics start off by drinking every day, it happens slowly and never do they think they will become addicts.

Well, do you react this way to your friends who drink alcohol? It doesn't seem so. If you acknowledge the comparisons in potential addiction between both cocaine and alcohol, then why are you only concerned about cocaine? Shouldn't you feel the same way about *any* substance use that can ultimately lead to addiction?

It's foolish of anybody to definitively claim, "I'll never get addicted", because they simply can't predict that.

But there *are* plenty of people who buy and use cocaine every once in awhile during social occasions, without ever developing a dependence or otherwise having it impact their life outside of these occasions.

Alcohol can be as much of a slippery slope as coke can be. It's reasonable to feel worried about people and want them to be careful using recreational substances, but it doesn't make sense to selectively apply strict moral rules to some substances but not others.

31.author: Muted_Item_8665

Also if he's done it before and seems unreasonable he probably is now craving it which is infamously hard to stop. And he got a dealer's number too so he's definitely not quitting anytime soon. Also coke is the dumbest drug just because of how expensive it is, like out of all drugs to get addicted to why choose one that's so money-draining.

31.author: moonknuckles
31.body: Unless you're claiming that this person is straight-up lying about how many times they've done coke -- doing coke on one occasion, and then doing it a second time *3 months later* (after being offered it, not even intentionally seeking it out) doesn't exactly sound like "craving" or "not stopping anytime soon".

31.author: Muted_Item_8665
31.body: no I 100% believe him as people who are trying to convince their friends they aren't addicted to coke would never lie

31.author: moonknuckles
31.body:
While it *is* possible for cocaine (in powder form) to result in actual measurable dependence with just 1 or 2 uses, this is not common or likely. With that being the case, it's not only possible but *likely* that a person *is not* dependent on cocaine after only 2 times using it. This is especially true if there are several months in between uses.

Therefore, it is completely and unremarkably plausible for a person to declare that they're not experiencing addiction in this situation, and for them to be correct.

Why do you find it reasonable to automatically assume the absolute worst about a total stranger? While there's also a significant likelihood that you could be wrong?

My goal here isn't to deny or downplay the serious risks of substance use, but there's no sense in ignoring the actual facts of the matter.

34.author: TheWardenDemonreach

Because, and again, I'm going off my own experience being a mod on a couple forums back in the day, not reddit, if we needed a new mod, we would discuss it amongst ourselves and the admins. We would look at people who were active, generally posted good content and discouraged bad behaviour and reported bad posts. We would already know them, know that we would likely get on with them and and wouldn't need to gauge any intent.

So if some randomer asked to be a mod, it would just tell us that they want to be able to ban people because that is the most likely option since they could easily just help out by keeping reporting bad posts and discouraging people in the threads.

35.author: Mooowyyn

I'll give my very vague understanding on it... regular computing exists in a state of either zero or one and it takes some time to switch between the two states.

Quantum computing exists in a state of being both zero and one at the same time and neither zero or one at the same time... and when it is time to make a "decision" to be either zero or one it's nearly instantaneous.

By the looks of the link you provided, the magazines that are shown don’t look to be tailored for mass consumption; it looks like they’re more niche magazines with an intended audience of wealthy specialists.

These may very well pay for the perceived luxury and exclusivity of a physical copy. Also, as much of a magazine revenue derive from advertising, I would imagine that suitable advertisers would be willing to pay to get access to these high value individuals. Simply broadcasting their wares to all and sundry may very well debase the exclusivity of the publication whilst not necessarily increasing the exposure to the target market for advertisers.

38.author: Dense_Revenue_486
38.body:
The magazines stocked are not limited publishing. It’s not like Idea Ltd, for example. The only reason you get this impression is because they drive traffic to their physical stores. The experience is being upsold in person by trained sales associates.

This is reason to completely digitise this industry: not preserve it. We’re not talking about journalists paying their mortgage; we are talking about a wealthy few paying off their second homes. This is why I was shocked at your initial comment.

38.author: RickJLeanPaw
38.body:
Hmm.  I was speaking of recent examples I had in mind of trade magazines, where exclusivity (or just rank incompetence by the governing bodies over anything digital!) seems to keep things physical, but I see that there’s some photo-based ones there as well.

In a previous life I’ve had photos of mine published in similar magazines, and it’s a much nicer feeling than just dumping some pixels onto a website.  The act of buying, then reading the magazine is much more specific and interactive than having a generic electronic device render pixels for you.
I suspect that this tangibility and user engagement is something these niche magazines still cleve to as the target audience will be less price-sensitive than the sleb gossip crowd.

44.author: Spokker
44.body:
HIPPA doesn't apply to the school district either. They comply with FERPA, though, and so does Aktivate. Aktivate is merely a third party platform meant to facilitate the district's digital custodianship of the records. The district is ultimately responsible for those records.

If the student athlete wants to keep it between them and their doctor, that's great. The questions are optional.

In the case of a lawful subpoena, Aktivate would produce the records without the consent of a student, provided they give reasonable notice to the student (so they can attempt to fight the subpoena if they choose), just as a school district would.

Not really seeing the issue here.

44.author: Addedinterest
44.body:
It's weird people are talking about this period tracking as 'normal' .

Maybe I'm the weird one, but no team I was on ever asked for that. **No one talked about telling their coach their period schedule**. You told your coach if you weren't feeling well, but the coach didn't need to know if you were having your period or when it would end...

None of my female friends or family has ever discussed mandatory period disclosure as being part of being on a team.

Not saying it's not useful information from one angle, but the disclosure as part of officialdom, and people who aren't your doctor being privy to it.

It's not a thing. It was never a normal thing and suddenly everyone is telling you it was.

44.author: Addedinterest
44.body:
My question was how are they able to tell the girls aren't lying.  


I think the groomers in FL are pushing hard for generating a high school girls team genital inspector job.  


 Its some really Christian Taliban sounding stuff. Everything Christians in the US criticize Islam for, they're ending up showing off that they have their own primitive era equivalent. Hymen inspections in Islam? Genital inspections on girls in Florida.

44.author: Spokker
44.body:
What it sounds like is a paranoid conspiracy theory. And there's no reason to lie because the questions are currently *optional*. Just don't answer them then. 

But I can think of a reason they *want* to ask the questions or perhaps even make them mandatory, and it has nothing to do with abortions, transgender issues or gender politics. It would have to do with *liability*.

Women athletes have higher rates of and more severe injuries on average compared to men. For example, ACL injuries are [6 times more common in women than men](https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/the-gender-gap-in-sports-injuries-201512038708), which is a killer injury for a sports career at any level. This is due to a variety of factors, most of them rooted in biological truths that differentiate males from females. 

Irregular periods have been linked to bone injuries in female student athletes. CHOP (a children's hospital) states that [irregular periods are not okay](https://www.chop.edu/news/health-tip/connection-between-diet-periods-and-stress-fractures-female-athletes) and that it can be a sign of reduced bone mass or insufficient caloric intake for sports. 

Now let's say a female student athlete suffers an injury during competition. The parents sue alleging that the coach pushed her too hard, the facilities were subpar, the safety equipment failed or some other thing. If a school district has a record of the student disclosing irregular periods, they can have their expert sit in court and testify that irregular periods are associated with a greater incidence of sports injuries. 

I think that's the ultimate reason why the school district would want such records, to protect themselves from liability. In their minds, they are doing their due diligence. Sure, you can lie, but a lot of people see an official form and answer the questions.

It should be sufficient to merely educate the student athletes and let them know they should monitor their periods. Some girls see losing their period after competing in high level sports as a "rite of passage," according to CHOP. Clearly there is a need to educate female athletes on this.

44.body: if by educate you mean mansplain how irregular periods work to high school girls... for your newfound interest in girls' sports. Then yes.

52.author: Teucer357
52.body:
Believe it or not, there is a federal mandate for healthcare workers to report injuries stemming from abuse...  Regardless of how that abuse occurred or who perpetuated it.

But I don't think that was your real question.  I think you want to know who they report it to and what happens after they do so.

The answer comes from a man named Frank Serpico.  An ex-policeman who successfully lobbied to have investigations of policemen handled by an independent agency rather than their own department.  Depending on the jurisdiction, this can be Internal Affairs (IA), Office of Professional Conduct (OPC), or the state may have a completely different agency such as the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE).

52.author: RRuruurrr
52.body:
>Believe it or not, there is a federal mandate for healthcare workers to report injuries stemming from abuse

Can you please show me where this exists in the US Code?

52.author: Teucer357
52.body:
Made me look it up.  I was under the impression it was a CMS mandate, but I'm actuality it isn't.  Instead, every US state (along with Puerto Rico and US Samoa) have individual laws regarding Mandated Reporting.

So, it's a universal mandate rather than a federal mandate.

52.author: RRuruurrr
52.body: Very good. In my State, for example, we are only required to report *child* abuse or neglect.

55.author: Miles_1995
55.body: Socialism is a broad category of movements characterized above all else by SOCIAL ownership of the means of production. It's right in the name. It is explicitly not "when the gubmit does stuff." The government may sometimes do things that are a step towards more equitable allocation of resources, which has a similar outcome, but conflating the two is like saying  "architecture is when an animal does stuff," because sometimes beavers make dams.

55.author: Teucer357
55.body:
The suffix "ism" means "doctrine"...  Thus the name "socialism" is "social doctrine".  "Ownership" isn't part of the word at all.  

In fact, the dictionary definition of "socialism" is the control of production by society **BY OWNERSHIP OR REGULATION**.  Feel free to look it up.

An expanded definition takes into account what is called "Chinese Socialism", which is where the State sets itself up in direct competition to private industry.  An example of "Chinese Socialism" in the US would be public schools.  Public schools are state run and in direct competition with private schools.  Thus, the State sets a minimum standard private schools must exceed in some way in order to exist.

55.author: Miles_1995
55.body:
I know what a suffix is. That's why I emphasized the "social" part and not the "ism" part, or any other word for that matter. You're being deliberately obtuse pretending otherwise.   


And just because there's an expanded definition of a word that some may use in certain contexts, it doesn't retroactively change the meaning of the original word in all contexts. You might as well be arguing that salads are actually sandwiches if you're this insistent on dancing around the definition of words to obscure whatever point you're trying to make.

  
Y having traits of X does not imply X has traits of Y

55.author: Teucer357
55.body:
The original definition is "control of production **THROUGH OWNERSHIP OR REGULATION**."

Again, **OWNERSHIP OR REGULATION**

You keep trying to argue that it only means "ownership" which would be communism, not socialism.

55.author: Miles_1995
55.body: Making something **BOLD FACE** doesn't change what you're talking about.  I never argued it never involves regulation, just that your specific example stretches the definition into the realm of pure semantics.

55.author: Teucer357
55.body:
If it wasn't you who argued "socialism means ownership by society.  It's in the name" then my apologies.

That said, "Chinese Socialism" is now considered a valid form of socialism.

56.author: nic0lk
56.body:
Well, I would counter that by saying that I believe it's beneficial to have an understanding of how our universe works—and astrology just ain't it. Any legitimate astronomer or physicist or cosmologist is going to say that the countless experiments we've done and evidence we've acquired point to astrology not being a thing.

So you're not hurting anyone by believing it, but it's based off of a fundamental misunderstanding of how things work, and I think that's important to know. If astrology is real, what else could be real? If you're willing to accept astrology based on anecdotal evidence, what else could you accept just on anecdotal evidence?

56.author: IronicHyperbole
56.body:
I think that people can understand basic science and still believe in the supernatural/unexplainable. 

You make a good point about broader scientific literacy, but I think my point still stands that it's not really your job to police others' beliefs, especially if it's unwarranted. 

For example, everyone clowns on Neil Degrasse Tyson for being the "well akshully" guy on Twitter whenever a new sci Fi movie comes out because he is missing the point that people are watching it for fun, and not for scientific accuracy. 

So my point is, if you want to have friends, don't be that guy.

56.author: nic0lk
56.body:
haha that's fair enough, and I think you're right. It's not my place to police people's beliefs and nobody likes the "well akshully" guy. 

If it's just a fun curiosity then I understand. But when my friend is showing my other friends *their* astrology map and saying "so between these lines are where you're not supposed to live because the energy will be off" and my other friends are going "ohhh that's interesting" it's *sooooo* hard not to say *that's not how this works! that's not how any of this works!*

But the upshot is I don't think my friend likes it when I challenge their belief in astrology so I'll try not to anymore.

60.author: TheUncaringVoid
60.body:
Absolutely. Some of these are bad habits like drinking a lot of milk even though I know that when I have milk it makes me also want other bad foods like donuts, ice cream, cookies. It just makes me feel comfortable to have milk when I'm thirsty instead of water or coffee a lot of the time. I like to drink beer or liquor sometimes and I know that honestly it mostly just gives me almost instant hangovers and a queasy feeling through the next day.

Some of the things are more addictive problems. I am a workaholic. I work at a library and the expectations of me are pretty low, but I'm constantly pushing myself to just go, go, go. Pull the most books, sort the most books, shelve the most books, be the fastest, do the most, prove myself. There is an indomitable and painful need to prove every day that I am valuable. It is just a holdover from a rough childhood and so I sort of know that in some form, this problem exists for me and it is part of my life to seek that proof of worth.

Some things are just traits that I know are terrible that I secretly feel are just part of who I am, and so I am invested in not changing them. I'm terribly stubborn and will live with discomfort for years even if only to not have to change whatever decision I've made about something. I don't need to be right, I don't need to be happy, but I feel an incredibly strong attachment to getting to do whatever I've decided to do even against a lot of negative consequence because it is what I chose. I know this is also probably a holdover from childhood trauma, but being stubborn feels very much like a part of who I am and so I just try to be careful about locking a decision in when I know it will involve other people. In general that is true of these problems, I want ot make sure even if I've accepted these negative things, that I am doing what I can to make sure they aren't harming other people directly.

64.author: wjbc
64.body: Would one of those mistakes be failing to capitalize “people” in the above sentence?

64.author: bazmonkey
64.body:
Well, OP was quoting the Bill of Rights, the first *amendments* to the Constitution.  By that time Congress had decided to drop the capitalization rule, but several were inconsistently left capitalized.  So technically in that quote, the still-capitalized common nouns are the mistakes.

https://blog.tenthamendmentcenter.com/2011/04/the-constitution-capitalization/

64.author: bazmonkey
64.body: Yeah.  Overall they weren’t fretting over the capitalization all that much.  It wasn’t until literacy became way more common that we began to really care about inconsistencies like this.

65.author: yyxsydney
65.body: According to some site I found, there are approximately 30,000 people in the US named Jillian. If we (generously) assume that the rate of Jillians is the same worldwide, there'd be around 750,000 in total. Not even a single million of Jillians. Heartbreaking, honestly.

65.author: Orculear
65.body:
What math did you use for this? Cause if there’s 30k Jillian’s, and as you said we generously assumed there’s the same amount worldwide, 
30,000 x 195 (number of countries in the world) would bring the total to 5,850,000 Jillian’s.

65.author: yyxsydney
65.body:
I assumed that the proportion of Jillians was the same globally, not that there were the same number in each country.

30,000 Jillians / 320 million (US population) = 0.009% (percentage of folks named Jillian)
0.009% \* 8 billion (world population) = 750,000 global Jillians

74.author: JustSomeApparition
74.body:
I understand that part, and I know what they mean. 

IThe notion of the idea of self-fulfilling prophecy still includes an aspect of prophecy to the term.

That's all I was asking because to believe in the notion of self-fulfilling prophecies but to deny the notion of prophecy seem to be contradictory.

I'm not saying you did but I was just wondering is all. If both were to exist as a notion I was just going to see the thought process behind that as to how to balance the terms is all

***Post Edit***

Prophetic, which is what your initial statement alluded too, is a bit different the umbrella that encompasses all that prophecy is. - to deny the existence of a prophet and one's ability to be prophetic, for some, is not directly tied into the concept of prophecy as a whole.

74.author: NetAFut
74.body: To prophecy the future is, in my opinion, not the same as a self fulfilling prophecy. We simply have no other common term for that which we refer to as a self fulfilling prophecy.

74.author: JustSomeApparition
74.body:
*Prophecy is a noun that means prediction. Specifically, it's a prediction that is delivered by a prophet, who is usually, though not always, a person instilled with their prognostic powers by a divine being. Prophecy tends to carry more weight than an everyday prediction, forecast, or educated guess.*

*Prophesy, on the other hand, is a verb that describes the action of making a prophetic prediction. As with the noun, a prophet most commonly prophesies under divine influence.*

*Prophesize is to reveal or foretell (something, esp a future event) by or as if by divine inspiration.*

*Being Prophetic has to do with the accuracy of being able to prophesize a prophecy.*

*Self-fulfilling prophecy, is the process through which an originally false expectation leads to its own confirmation. In a self-fulfilling prophecy an individual's expectations about another person or entity eventually result in the other person or entity acting in ways that confirm the expectations.*

A self-fulfilling prophecy is what you seen the results would be of that person's doings as caused by their actions. It is not them seeing. The outsider is the one making the prophecy.
